text:
Created attachment 31909
Patch for simpler code

The cipher code in openssl syntax could take advantage of varargs to make it easier to use.
creator: emmanuel.hugonnet@gmail.com

text:
Created attachment 31910
Fixing the patch as it was in reverse mode

Fixing the patch as it was in reverse mode
creator: emmanuel.hugonnet@gmail.com

text: In the current code the jsse and openssl names are near each other. It makes it  easier to review them. Your patch breaks that, so I am -1.
creator: knst.kolinko@gmail.com
remm@apache.org
text:
Let's see if someone seconds your "veto", which is not justified with legitimate arguments at the moment since varargs are probably cleaner in the code than arrays. So for now, it is invalid, please change that to -0 at least :)

I'd also like to remind that Emmanuel is the author of the OpenSSL code that was contributed..

creator: fhanik@apache.org
text:
(In reply to Remy Maucherat from comment #3)
> Let's see if someone seconds your "veto", which is not justified with
> legitimate arguments at the moment since varargs are probably cleaner in the
> code than arrays. So for now, it is invalid, please change that to -0 at
> least :)

I agree with Remy on this one. -1 rejection based on code style is something we must move away from in order to encourage more contributions. It's already hard enough to contribute code through patches as it is.

Hum I don't agree : you have a lot of null values or a lot of verbosity with arrays which leads to less readibility.
In the current code you have :
 - jsse name (as a enum constant)
 - openssl name
 - jsse aliases

Also I might add that moving the aliases to the end makes the code closer to the declaration in openssl code.
creator: emmanuel.hugonnet@gmail.com

text:
(In reply to Remy Maucherat from comment #3)
Ack. I revoke my veto and abstain from voting.
I still do not see much worth in this patch.
creator: knst.kolinko@gmail.com

text:
Remy has applied this path so closing the issue.

I too preferred the JSSE names closer to the OpenSSL names which is why I didn't use varargs when I added the JSSE names in the first place. The var args is cleaner but it does make it a little harder to review since the names are further apart. I guess this makes me -0 on the move to varargs.

The original patch could have done more on the cleaner code front by making the formatting of the cipher definitions more consistent rather than less consistent. I've just done a couple of global search and replaces to fix the inconsistencies introduced by this patch and some others I spotted.

The original patch also introduced some trailing whitespace (now removed) and a redundant type argument (also removed).
creator: markt@apache.org
remm@apache.org
text: Sorry for the formatting trouble. I understand the order argument.
